> This sounds like a cool idea, but I don't quite get how the  
> competition works.  Are you playing against other entrants into the  
> competition?

Exactly. The whole point of the competition is that the strengths and  
weaknesses of various general game players are analyzed (there are  
also random and minimax reference players). All entrants basically  
play in three, week-long qualifier rounds (consisting of 20 games)  
which one would assume pairs all the players on each of the games.

> Is there a set number of possible types of games (or are they able  
> to generate novel games based on variations of existing ones)?

The set of possible games is really only limited by the programming  
skill of the game implementors. The specification language is very  
general. There are a few basic requirements that each valid game must  
meet (e.g. finite-length), but beyond that anything is fine. In  
addition to the games I've already mentioned there is a whole slew of  
other games, some of which I've heard of and some of which were  
created just for the competition. My favorite is a game called  
farmers which is basically a really complicated version of lemonade  
stand with three players. The final competition will consist of  
previously unreleased games, to avoid hard-coded strategies as much  
as possible.

> Do you play a mixture of games each round or just one?  It would  
> seem unfair for some entrants to have to learn Tic-Tac-Toe one  
> round while others learn Chess.

Each round is going to be a mixture of games, and I assume each  
player will be evaluated on the same games (hopefully a full round- 
robin tournament).

> How do they handle situations like draws?  Just settling on a rule  
> set for a Go competition would seem difficult enough.

Each game has a set of goal conditions which detail how many points  
each player receives for various terminal states. Unfortunately, full- 
blown Go is probably out of the question for the spec language.

> Per NEAT, is there any training/evolution that occurs prior to the  
> competition, or do you basically start evolving the population from  
> scratch during the competition, once you receive the rule set?

After the spec is received, there is some amount of time for initial  
learning before the match commences. For now we're just starting from  
scratch. I'm not convinced that we can do any meaningful neural  
network "pre-patterning" given our current architecture. Eventually  
we'd like to explore using SOMs for the input layer, and at that  
point it definitely becomes an option though.

-- Joe
